messageBody:
Pleae have a look at JUnit faq at
http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm
Section 4 titled 'Writing Tests' item 4.

/Sreenivasa Majji.



--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Andrew Forward <aforward@g...> wrote:
> To test private methods or member variables, you can look to JUnitX
> (some examples are available at http://www.extreme-java.de/junitx/).
>
> Following this email is an uncompiled example of how you might test
> the above code using JUnitX.
>
> Now, taking design into consideration - the need to test private
stuff
> is often seen as being a code smell (just google 'testing private
> methods code smell'). In essence, if your private stuff is doing
> things that requires explicit testing - then maybe it is really
trying
> to become its own class (with its own set of tests) to which your
> existing class can use (and use confidently as there are ample tests
> demonstrating its proper functionality).
>
> andrew f
>
> ``````````````````````````````````
> package example;
>
> import junit.framework.*;
> import junitx.framework.*;
>
> public class SampleTest extends PrivateTestCase
> {
> public SampleTest (string name)
> {
> super(name);
> }
>
> public void testChange()
> {
> Object myObject = newInstance ("example.Sample", NOARGS);
> Object performChange = invokeWithKey (myObject, "change",
NOARGS);
>
> assertEquals (10, getInt(myObject, "x"));
>
> }
>
> }
>
> ``````````````````````````````````
>
>
>
> On Thu, 26 Aug 2004 22:41:18 +0900, jae.woo.lee <jae.woo.lee@s...>
wrote:
> >
> > I think you can add a getter method for 'x' and check the value
using
> > assertEquals() method.
> > For example,
> > class Sample {
> > ....
> > public int getX() {
> > return x;
> > }
> > }
> >
> > and in the Test Class, add the following Method
> >
> > public void testChangeX() {
> > Sample s = new Sample();
> > s.change();
> > assertEquals(10, s.getX());
> > }
> >
> > Now, the Test done!!
> >
> > - Jaewoo
